metadata.subject: physics
metadata.dotPoint: calculate the de Broglie wavelength of matter: λ = h/p

matter_wave_hypothesis.name: Matter Wave Hypothesis
matter_wave_hypothesis.correct: de Broglie proposed that ALL matter has an associated wavelength, not just electrons or small particles.

only electrons.error: Too restrictive. Electrons were first tested, but the hypothesis applies universally.
only electrons.fix: de Broglie proposed that everything with momentum has a wavelength.
only electrons.action: Calculate the de Broglie wavelength of a running person. It exists, just unmeasurably small.

only charged particles.error: Charge is irrelevant. Neutrons diffract despite being neutral.
only charged particles.fix: The formula λ = h/p contains no charge term. Momentum is what matters.
only charged particles.action: Look up neutron diffraction. Neutrons are uncharged but still exhibit wave behaviour.

only subatomic particles.error: Size does not limit applicability, only measurability.
only subatomic particles.fix: Baseballs have de Broglie wavelengths too, just immeasurably small.
only subatomic particles.action: Calculate a cricket ball's wavelength. Why is it too small to observe?

persistent.gap: You are not grasping the universality of wave-particle duality.
persistent.action: Key insight: λ = h/p applies to EVERYTHING with momentum. The only limit is measurement precision.

debroglie_formula.name: de Broglie Wavelength Formula
debroglie_formula.correct: λ = h/p. Planck's constant divided by momentum gives wavelength in metres.

λ = p/h.fix: Planck's constant h on top, momentum p on bottom: λ = h/p.
λ = p/h.action: Check: does your formula give smaller λ for larger p? That's the correct relationship.

λ = hp.fix: λ = h/p means h DIVIDED BY p, not multiplied.
λ = hp.action: Check units: (J·s)/(kg·m/s) = metres. Does hp give metres?

λ = h/mv².fix: de Broglie uses momentum (mv), not energy-related terms (mv²).
λ = h/mv².action: Distinguish: p = mv for momentum, KE = ½mv² for kinetic energy.

λ = hf.error: That relates energy and frequency, not wavelength and momentum.
λ = hf.fix: E = hf relates energy to frequency. λ = h/p relates wavelength to momentum.
λ = hf.action: Know both: E = hf for photon energy, λ = h/p for de Broglie wavelength.

persistent.gap: You are confusing related quantum formulas.
persistent.action: Write out λ = h/p, E = hf, and p = h/λ. Understand which connects which quantities.

momentum_wavelength_relationship.name: Momentum-Wavelength Relationship
momentum_wavelength_relationship.correct: Wavelength is INVERSELY proportional to momentum. Greater momentum means shorter wavelength.

directly proportional.fix: p is in the denominator. Larger denominator means smaller result.
directly proportional.action: Calculate λ for p = 1 and p = 10. Which gives a larger wavelength?

proportional to momentum squared.error: No squared term. Simple inverse relationship.
proportional to momentum squared.fix: λ = h/p has p to the first power only.
proportional to momentum squared.action: The formula is λ = h/p, not λ = h/p². No squaring needed.

independent of momentum.error: They are directly linked by λ = h/p.
independent of momentum.fix: Momentum is the only variable affecting de Broglie wavelength.
independent of momentum.action: Substitute different momentum values. The wavelength changes.

persistent.gap: You do not understand inverse proportionality.
persistent.action: When a variable is in the denominator, increasing it DECREASES the result. Practice with numbers.

planck_constant_value.name: Planck's Constant
planck_constant_value.correct: h = 6.63 × 10⁻³⁴ J·s in SI units. Use this value for de Broglie calculations.

6.63 × 10⁻²⁷ J·s.error: Wrong exponent. Off by 7 orders of magnitude.

6.63 × 10⁻³⁴ eV·s.error: Wrong units. SI uses joules, not electron-volts.
6.63 × 10⁻³⁴ eV·s.fix: h = 6.63 × 10⁻³⁴ J·s for de Broglie calculations.
6.63 × 10⁻³⁴ eV·s.action: For wavelength/momentum, use J·s. The eV·s value is for energy-frequency work.

1.06 × 10⁻³⁴ J·s.action: de Broglie formula uses h, not ℏ. Know the difference.

persistent.gap: You need to memorise this fundamental constant.
persistent.action: Flashcard: h = 6.63 × 10⁻³⁴ J·s. Review until automatic.

electron_diffraction_evidence.name: Electron Diffraction as Evidence
electron_diffraction_evidence.correct: Electron diffraction patterns prove electrons behave as waves, confirming de Broglie's hypothesis.

photon behaviour.fix: Electron diffraction shows MATTER waves exist, extending wave-particle duality from light to matter.
photon behaviour.action: Distinguish: photon diffraction was known. Electron diffraction was new evidence.

classical particle motion.fix: Diffraction is exclusively a wave phenomenon. Particles showing it proves wave nature.
classical particle motion.action: What would a classical particle pattern look like? Two bands, not an interference pattern.

random scattering.error: Diffraction patterns are ordered, not random.
random scattering.fix: The regular ring pattern shows constructive and destructive interference.
random scattering.action: Compare electron diffraction to X-ray diffraction. Both show ordered patterns.

persistent.gap: You do not connect diffraction with wave behaviour.
persistent.action: Core logic: Only waves diffract. Electrons diffract. Therefore electrons have wave properties.

wavelength_speed_relationship.name: Effect of Speed on Wavelength
wavelength_speed_relationship.correct: Faster objects have shorter de Broglie wavelengths. Speed is inversely related to wavelength.

increases.error: Opposite. Faster means more momentum, thus shorter wavelength.
increases.fix: λ = h/(mv). Larger v in denominator means smaller λ.
increases.action: Calculate wavelength at v = 100 m/s and v = 200 m/s. Which is smaller?

stays constant.error: Wavelength depends directly on speed through momentum.
stays constant.fix: Since p = mv, changing v changes p, which changes λ.
stays constant.action: The formula λ = h/p = h/(mv) shows explicit v dependence.

depends on charge.error: Charge does not appear in the de Broglie formula.
depends on charge.fix: Only mass and velocity affect the wavelength: λ = h/(mv).
depends on charge.action: Check the formula. No charge term exists.

persistent.gap: You are not tracing the dependence through the formula.
persistent.action: Write λ = h/(mv). Speed is in denominator. Bigger speed → smaller wavelength.

wavelength_mass_relationship.name: Effect of Mass on Wavelength
wavelength_mass_relationship.correct: More massive objects have shorter de Broglie wavelengths at the same speed.

increases.error: Opposite. Greater mass means greater momentum, thus shorter wavelength.
increases.fix: λ = h/(mv). Larger m in denominator means smaller λ.
increases.action: Compare wavelengths of electron and proton at same speed. Proton has shorter λ.

independent of mass.error: Mass directly affects wavelength through momentum.
independent of mass.fix: Since p = mv, mass is explicitly in the de Broglie formula.
independent of mass.action: The formula λ = h/(mv) contains m. It cannot be independent.

depends on charge.error: Charge is irrelevant. Mass and velocity determine wavelength.
depends on charge.fix: The formula λ = h/(mv) has no charge term.
depends on charge.action: Neutrons have no charge but still have de Broglie wavelengths.

persistent.gap: You do not recognise how mass affects quantum wavelength.
persistent.action: Compare: electron mass vs proton mass. At same speed, which has shorter wavelength?

macroscopic_wavelength.name: Macroscopic de Broglie Wavelengths
macroscopic_wavelength.correct: Macroscopic objects have de Broglie wavelengths, but they are immeasurably small (10⁻³⁴ m range).

do not have wavelengths.error: All matter has a de Broglie wavelength by definition.
do not have wavelengths.fix: The formula applies universally. Large objects just have undetectably small wavelengths.
do not have wavelengths.action: Calculate a 150g cricket ball's wavelength at 20 m/s. It exists, about 10⁻³⁴ m.

have observable wave behaviour.error: Wavelength must be comparable to object/gap size for observable diffraction.
have observable wave behaviour.fix: λ/w ratio must approach 1 for significant diffraction. Macroscopic λ/w ≈ 0.
have observable wave behaviour.action: A person's wavelength is 10⁻³⁶ m. Doorway is 1 m. Ratio is 10⁻³⁶—no diffraction.

have wavelengths around 1 nm.error: Far too large. Macroscopic wavelengths are around 10⁻³⁴ m.
have wavelengths around 1 nm.fix: 1 nm = 10⁻⁹ m is typical for electrons. Macroscopic objects have wavelengths 25 orders smaller.
have wavelengths around 1 nm.action: Calculate for a running person. The wavelength is about 10⁻³⁶ m.

persistent.gap: You do not appreciate the scale difference between quantum and classical.
persistent.action: Calculate wavelengths for electron, atom, bacterium, cricket ball, person. Note the progression.

photon_electron_diffraction_comparison.name: Comparing Photon and Electron Diffraction
photon_electron_diffraction_comparison.correct: Photons and electrons with the same wavelength produce diffraction patterns with identical spacing.

patterns are always different.error: Spacing depends only on wavelength and gap size, not particle type.
patterns are always different.fix: If λ is the same and the gap is the same, the pattern spacing is the same.
patterns are always different.action: Diffraction spacing depends on λ/w ratio, which is particle-independent.

electrons cannot produce patterns.fix: Davisson-Germer and Thomson experiments confirmed electron diffraction.
electrons cannot produce patterns.action: Research the 1927 experiments that confirmed de Broglie's hypothesis.

photons produce sharper patterns.error: Pattern sharpness depends on wavelength uniformity, not particle type.
photons produce sharper patterns.fix: Both photons and electrons produce clear patterns when properly collimated.
photons produce sharper patterns.action: Compare actual X-ray and electron diffraction images. Both show clear rings.

persistent.gap: You do not recognise that wave properties are universal.
persistent.action: Key insight: same wavelength means same diffraction behaviour, regardless of whether it's light or matter.

same_momentum_same_wavelength.name: Momentum-Wavelength Equivalence
same_momentum_same_wavelength.correct: A photon and a particle with the same momentum have the same de Broglie wavelength.

same energy means same wavelength.error: Energy and momentum are different quantities.
same energy means same wavelength.fix: Photon energy E = pc differs from matter kinetic energy KE = p²/2m.
same energy means same wavelength.action: Same p gives same λ. Same E does NOT give same p for photons vs matter.

only applies to matter.error: The relation p = h/λ applies to both photons and matter.
only applies to matter.fix: This is the universal momentum-wavelength relationship.
only applies to matter.action: Rearrange λ = h/p to get p = h/λ. Works for all quantum objects.

mass must be equal.error: Mass is not required to match. Momentum must match.
mass must be equal.fix: A photon (massless) and electron (massive) can have the same momentum.
mass must be equal.action: Calculate momentum needed for a photon to match an electron's wavelength.

persistent.gap: You are confusing momentum, energy, and mass relationships.
persistent.action: Memorise: λ = h/p links wavelength to momentum only. Energy is separate.

diffraction_ratio.name: Diffraction and λ/w Ratio
diffraction_ratio.correct: Significant diffraction occurs when the wavelength is comparable to the gap width (λ/w ≈ 1).

λ/w must be greater than 1.error: Diffraction is measurable when λ/w is roughly 0.01 or greater.
λ/w must be greater than 1.fix: λ/w ≈ 1 gives maximum spread, but smaller ratios still show some diffraction.
λ/w must be greater than 1.action: Measurable diffraction occurs for λ/w > 0.01 approximately.

only depends on wavelength.fix: Diffraction depends on the RATIO λ/w, not just λ alone.
only depends on wavelength.action: Same wavelength through different gaps gives different diffraction.

larger gaps give more diffraction.error: Opposite. Smaller gaps (larger λ/w) give more diffraction.
larger gaps give more diffraction.fix: λ/w increases when w decreases, giving greater spreading.
larger gaps give more diffraction.action: Why do electrons need atomic-scale gaps? Because λ is about 10⁻¹⁰ m.

persistent.gap: You do not understand how gap width affects diffraction.
persistent.action: Review: diffraction spread ∝ λ/w. Smaller gap or longer wavelength means more spreading.

electron_microscope_application.name: Electron Microscope Resolution
electron_microscope_application.correct: Electron microscopes achieve higher resolution than light microscopes because electrons have shorter wavelengths.

electrons are smaller than photons.error: Size is not the relevant factor. Wavelength is.
electrons are smaller than photons.fix: Resolution is limited by diffraction, which depends on wavelength.
electrons are smaller than photons.action: High-energy electrons have wavelengths around 10⁻¹² m, much shorter than visible light.

electrons do not diffract.error: Electrons do diffract. That is how we know they have wave properties.
electrons do not diffract.fix: All imaging involves some diffraction. Shorter wavelength means less spreading.
electrons do not diffract.action: Electron diffraction was demonstrated in 1927. It is real and measurable.

electron charge provides better imaging.error: Charge affects focusing with magnetic lenses, but resolution comes from wavelength.
electron charge provides better imaging.fix: The fundamental resolution limit is set by wavelength, not charge.
electron charge provides better imaging.action: Compare: light wavelength ~500 nm, electron wavelength ~0.001 nm.

persistent.gap: You do not connect wavelength to imaging resolution.
persistent.action: Key principle: Shorter wavelength → less diffraction → sharper images → higher resolution.

matter_waves.instructions: Complete the dropdowns to demonstrate your understanding of de Broglie's matter wave hypothesis.

sentences.text: In 1924, Louis de Broglie proposed that {{d1}} has wave-like properties and an associated wavelength. This hypothesis extended wave-particle duality from {{d2}} to matter.

d2.tooltip: Which particles already had known wave properties before de Broglie?

sentences.text: The wave-like nature of matter was confirmed in 1927 when {{d3}} were observed to {{d4}}. This behaviour is exclusively associated with waves, not classical particles.

d3.tooltip: Which particles were first demonstrated to show matter wave behaviour?

d4.tooltip: What wave phenomenon creates interference patterns?

d3.tooltip: Check your data sheet for the SI value

d4.tooltip: What units ensure the result is in metres?

sentences.text: Since p = mv, the de Broglie formula can also be written as λ = {{d5}}. This shows that wavelength is {{d6}} proportional to both mass and velocity.

d5.tooltip: Substitute p = mv into λ = h/p

d6.tooltip: Mass and velocity are in the denominator

diffraction_comparison.title: Comparing Diffraction Patterns
diffraction_comparison.instructions: Complete the dropdowns to show your understanding of how photon and electron diffraction compare.

d1.tooltip: Which EM waves have wavelengths comparable to electron wavelengths?

d2.tooltip: What type of behaviour produces diffraction patterns?

sentences.text: A photon and an electron with the same {{d3}} will produce diffraction patterns with {{d4}} spacing.

d4.tooltip: Same momentum means same wavelength means same pattern

matter_waves.title: Applying Matter Wave Concepts
matter_waves.instructions: Apply your understanding of matter waves to these scenarios.

sentences.text: De Broglie's hypothesis that matter has wave properties was confirmed when Davisson and Germer observed electrons creating {{d1}} patterns. This earned de Broglie the {{d2}} Prize in Physics.

Wave-particle duality means that matter can demonstrate both {{d3}} properties, depending on the experiment. The wavelength is only observable when it is {{d4}} the size of objects the particle interacts with.
A common misconception is that only {{d5}} have de Broglie wavelengths. In reality, even {{d6}} have associated wavelengths, though immeasurably small.

d5.tooltip: What type of particles do students often incorrectly limit this to?

d6.tooltip: The formula applies to everything, including large objects

debroglie_formula.title: Working with the de Broglie Formula
debroglie_formula.instructions: Apply your knowledge of the de Broglie formula to these problems.

sentences.text: To calculate the de Broglie wavelength of an electron moving at 2.0 × 10⁶ m/s, you would first calculate its {{d1}}, then divide {{d2}} by this value.

d1.tooltip: What quantity appears in the denominator of λ = h/p?

d2.tooltip: What goes in the numerator of λ = h/p?

sentences.text: An electron accelerated through 100 V has kinetic energy of 100 eV. To find its de Broglie wavelength, you must first convert this energy to find {{d3}}, then apply λ = {{d4}}.

d3.tooltip: The formula relates wavelength to momentum, not energy directly

sentences.text: When using the de Broglie formula, if momentum is in kg·m/s and Planck's constant is in {{d5}}, the resulting wavelength will be in {{d6}}.

calculations.title: de Broglie Calculations in Context
calculations.instructions: Apply calculation skills to practical scenarios.

sentences.text: Comparing a proton and an electron travelling at the same speed, the proton has approximately {{d3}} times the momentum and therefore approximately {{d4}} the de Broglie wavelength.

d4.tooltip: Wavelength is inversely proportional to momentum

sentences.text: A neutron used in diffraction experiments typically has a wavelength of about 0.2 nm, similar to {{d5}} spacing. This makes neutrons useful for studying {{d6}} structure.

d5.tooltip: Atoms are separated by about 0.1-0.5 nm in crystals

d6.tooltip: What structures have spacing of about 0.2 nm?

diffraction_comparison.title: Analysing Diffraction Experiments
diffraction_comparison.instructions: Apply your understanding to compare diffraction patterns.

sentences.text: If X-rays and electrons produce diffraction patterns with identical ring spacing when passing through the same crystal, we can conclude they have the same {{d1}} and therefore the same {{d2}}.

d2.tooltip: Wavelength and momentum are linked by λ = h/p

sentences.text: Electron microscopes can resolve smaller objects than light microscopes because electrons can have much {{d3}} wavelengths than visible light, reducing {{d4}} effects.

d3.tooltip: High-energy electrons have wavelengths around 10⁻¹² m

d4.tooltip: What phenomenon limits resolution in imaging?

sentences.text: When comparing diffraction patterns, electrons and X-rays show {{d5}} ring patterns when they have matching {{d6}}. The particle type does not affect the pattern shape.

d5.tooltip: Same wavelength through same gap gives...

matter_waves.title: Mastering Matter Wave Concepts
matter_waves.instructions: Demonstrate complete understanding of matter waves and their implications.

sentences.text: The wave nature of matter explains why electron diffraction patterns show {{d1}} and {{d2}} bands, the same features seen in light wave interference.
A key insight from wave-particle duality is that the wave properties of matter are always present, but only {{d3}} when the object's wavelength is {{d4}} the scale of interaction.

d3.tooltip: The wavelength exists always; what changes is detectability

sentences.text: Neutron diffraction is used in materials science despite neutrons being {{d5}}. This demonstrates that de Broglie wavelength depends on {{d6}}, not charge.

d5.tooltip: What is special about neutron charge?

d6.tooltip: Look at the formula λ = h/p. No charge term.

debroglie_formula.title: de Broglie Formula Mastery
debroglie_formula.instructions: Demonstrate complete mastery of the de Broglie relationship.

sentences.text: The relationship λ = h/p shows that wavelength is determined by momentum {{d1}}. This means a photon with momentum p has {{d2}} de Broglie wavelength as a particle with the same momentum.

d1.tooltip: What variables appear in λ = h/p?

d2.tooltip: Same p gives same h/p regardless of particle type

sentences.text: Converting between energy and de Broglie wavelength for matter requires knowing that p = {{d3}}, unlike photons where p = {{d4}}.

d3.tooltip: Rearrange KE = p²/2m to find p

d4.tooltip: From E = pc, solve for p

sentences.text: Confusion often arises between λ = h/p and E = hf. The formula λ = h/p applies to {{d5}}, while E = hf applies specifically to calculate {{d6}}.

d5.tooltip: The de Broglie relation is universal

d6.tooltip: E = hf relates energy and frequency for light

calculations.title: Advanced de Broglie Calculations
calculations.instructions: Apply de Broglie concepts to complex scenarios.

sentences.text: For an electron accelerated from rest through potential difference V, the kinetic energy equals {{d1}}, allowing calculation of de Broglie wavelength using λ = h/{{d2}}.

d1.tooltip: Work done by electric field equals charge times voltage

d2.tooltip: Combine KE = eV with KE = p²/2m

sentences.text: If an electron's de Broglie wavelength equals a photon's wavelength, the electron must have {{d3}} momentum as the photon, but {{d4}} energy.

d3.tooltip: Same λ means same h/λ = p

d4.tooltip: For matter: KE = p²/2m. For photon: E = pc. At same p, which is larger?

sentences.text: Doubling an electron's kinetic energy multiplies its momentum by {{d5}} and therefore multiplies its de Broglie wavelength by {{d6}}.

d5.tooltip: KE = p²/2m, so p = √(2mKE). If KE doubles, p becomes √2 times larger.

d6.tooltip: λ = h/p. If p multiplies by √2, λ divides by √2.

diffraction_comparison.title: Complete Diffraction Analysis
diffraction_comparison.instructions: Synthesise your understanding of photon and matter diffraction.

d2.tooltip: Electron wavelengths are typically 10⁻¹² to 10⁻¹⁰ m

sentences.text: X-rays with wavelength 0.1 nm have momentum of approximately {{d3}} kg·m/s. An electron with this same momentum would travel at approximately {{d4}} m/s.

When electrons pass through a single narrow slit, they produce a diffraction pattern that proves their {{d5}} nature. Each electron contributes {{d6}} to the pattern, yet the overall pattern shows wave interference.
